In this nlab entry: Karoubi envelope, they say that the category of smooth manifold is (equivalent, isomorphic? to) the idempotent-splitting completion of the category of open subspaces of cartesian spaces. In remark 1.2, it is said that the 222-sphere can be represented as say (R3\{0},e)(\mathbb{R}^3\backslash \{0\},e)(R3\{0},e) where eee is the endomap of R3\{0}\mathbb{R}^3\backslash \{0\}R3\{0} defined by e(x)=x∣∣x∣∣e(x)=\frac{x}{||x||}e(x)=∣∣x∣∣x​.

It makes a lot of sense to me since in the usual representation of the category of smooth manifolds, we have this splitting of eee:
R3\{0}→rS2→sR3\{0}\mathbb{R}^3\backslash \{0\} \overset{r}{\rightarrow} S^2 \overset{s}{\rightarrow} \mathbb{R}^3\backslash \{0\}R3\{0}→rS2→sR3\{0}
where r(x)=x∣∣x∣∣r(x)=\frac{x}{||x||}r(x)=∣∣x∣∣x​, and S2S^2S2 is seen as the sphere of radius one centered at 000 in R3\mathbb{R}^3R3, and sss is the inclusion.

It is said in this same remark that the 2-sphere isn't (diffeomorphic) to an open subset of a cartesian space.

I don't know how to prove this.

Questions:

  • How to prove that the 222-sphere isn't diffeomorphic to an open subset of a cartesian space?
  • Is the stronger statement that the 222-sphere isn't homeomorphic to an open subset of a cartesian space true?
  • What about the other nnn-spheres?

I don't remember much about diffeomorphisms, sadly.

By "cartesian space" you mean Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn right? If so I can help for parts 2 and 3. Can you prove that nnn-spheres are compact?

(Hint: can you find a continuous injective embedding f:Sn↪Rn+1f:S^n\hookrightarrow\mathbb{R}^{n+1}f:Sn↪Rn+1 such that f(Sn)f(S^n)f(Sn) is closed and bounded?)

Eric M Downes said:

By "cartesian space" you mean Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn right?

Yes, exactly.
And diffeomorphic ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ homeomorphic, so not homeomorphic ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ not diffeomorphic.

Eric M Downes said:

(Hint: can you find a continuous injective embedding f:Sn↪Rn+1f:S^n\hookrightarrow\mathbb{R}^{n+1}f:Sn↪Rn+1 such that f(Sn)f(S^n)f(Sn) is closed and bounded?)

Yes, the usual representation of SnS^nSn is as the sphere of radius 111 centered at 000 in Rn+1\mathbb{R}^{n+1}Rn+1. With this representation, the embedding is just an inclusion.
Nice. So is it compact then?
(and is compactness a topological invariant?)
Ok, SnS^nSn is closed and bounded in Rn+1\mathbb{R}^{n+1}Rn+1, thus it is compact. But is it true that an open subset of cartesian space is never compact?
Well, compact = closed & bounded by Heine-Borel right? And under the usual topology of Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn there are very few clopen sets...

Hmm, an open subset of a cartesian space is homeomorphic to the open ball of radius 111 centered at 000 (through x↦x1−∣∣x∣∣x \mapsto \frac{x}{1-||x||}x↦1−∣∣x∣∣x​ whose inverse is x↦x1+∣∣x∣∣x \mapsto \frac{x}{1+||x||}x↦1+∣∣x∣∣x​)which is not compact because you can define a sequence which converges to the border.
Be careful though..... is (0,1)∪(2,3)(0,1)\cup(2,3)(0,1)∪(2,3) open?
Yes?
Why do I need to be careful?
Is simple-connectedness a topological invariant?
eg preserved by homeomorphisms

Hmm, an open subset of a cartesian space is homeomorphic to the open ball of radius 111 centered at 000 (through x↦x1−∣∣x∣∣x \mapsto \frac{x}{1-||x||}x↦1−∣∣x∣∣x​ whose inverse is x↦x1+∣∣x∣∣x \mapsto \frac{x}{1+||x||}x↦1+∣∣x∣∣x​)which is not compact because you can define a sequence which converges to the border.

Sorry, I don't think the first fact is true. I was thinking "Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn is homeomorphic to the open ball of radius 111 centered at 000".
yes! thats what I was getting at. Nice work.
Yeah, it is false, since an open set isn't necessarily connected.

Eric M Downes said:

Well, compact = closed & bounded by Heine-Borel right? And under the usual topology of Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn there are very few clopen sets...

Ok, this is the way to go I guess.

Ok, if UUU is a clopen set in Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn which is neither ∅\emptyset∅ nor Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn, then Rn\U\mathbb{R}^n \backslash URn\U is also clopen. So Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn is a disjoint union of nonempty open sets, thus Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn is not connected. But Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn is connected since it is path-connected.

To sum up:

  • The nnn-sphere is compact as a bounded closed subset of Rn+1\mathbb{R}^{n+1}Rn+1.
  • If the nnn-sphere is homeomorphic to an open subset UUU of an Rp\mathbb{R}^pRp, then UUU is compact, thus closed, thus a clopen. So UUU is either Rp\mathbb{R}^pRp or the empty set. The cardinality is preserved by homeomorphism, thus UUU is necessarily Rp\mathbb{R}^pRp.

Now, we have reduced the problem to the one of proving that the nnn-sphere isn't homeomorphic to an Rp\mathbb{R}^pRp.
Ok, I think I know how to finish.
I think you must show that the Rp\mathbb{R}^pRp is contractible but the nnn-sphere is not.

I would say they are both contractible to different things, but yes that is sufficient.

I mean, you don't need homotopy though. If you know what homeomorphisms preserve, you can see it directly, which is maybe more categorical? Anyway, I think you're good; I gotta go though, so good luck!

Oh yeah sorry forgot that people use "contractible" to mean "contractible to a point" instead of say "contractible to a loop" etc. Sorry, I always found that confusing and must have chosen to forget it lol.
Anyway, I wanted to say that the nnn-sphere is not contractible (if n≥1n \ge 1n≥1) because Hn(Sn)≅ZH^n(S^n) \cong \mathbb{Z}Hn(Sn)≅Z.
Oh, maybe it's overkill.
It's easier to show that Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn is not compact I think.
It's not compact because it is not a bounded subset of itself.

Ok, so you just have to say this:

Let n≥1n \ge 1n≥1.

  • The nnn-sphere is compact as a bounded closed subset of Rn+1\mathbb{R}^{n+1}Rn+1.
  • If the nnn-sphere is homeomorphic to an open subset UUU of an Rp\mathbb{R}^pRp, then UUU is compact, thus closed, thus a clopen. So UUU is either Rp\mathbb{R}^pRp or the empty set. The cardinality is preserved by homeomorphism, thus UUU is necessarily Rp\mathbb{R}^pRp. Thus Rp\mathbb{R}^pRp is compact. But Rp\mathbb{R}^pRp is not compact if p≥1p \ge 1p≥1 because it is a subset of Rp\mathbb{R}^pRp which is not bounded. Hence, p=0p=0p=0. Thus SnS^nSn is homeomorphic to a point which is false because it is an infinite set.
